title: Portable Radio, "Pocketable radio", 1960
provenance: ca. 1960: purchased new by Max Pine; 2012: acquired by Museum
dimensions: H x W x D: 8.9 x 6 x 2.5 cm (3 1/2 in. x 2 3/8 in. x 1 in.)
description: Small rectangular white plastic body; front with white metal panel with station indicator, "SONY" logo and "SIX TRANSISTOR," above large, circular, gold-toned pierced metal speaker with recessed asterisk-shaped design; black strap handle on left side; two small white control dials on right side; hinged white metal battery compartment in lower rear.
justification:
The radio is the first and oldest product in the Sony&nbsp;electronics range, and helped the company to achieve international acclaim. Over time,&nbsp;Sony&nbsp;miniaturized and simplified&nbsp;its radio designs, offering them in&nbsp;fewer case colors&nbsp;and with less decoration. The TR-620, introduced in 1960, is a middle example of this evolution. The TR-55,&nbsp;introduced in&nbsp;1955, was the first of Sony’s transistor radios and its first export. The TR-620’s more immediate predecessor, the TR-610 of 1958, was the first radio to include the now-ubiquitous Sony logo typeface,&nbsp;and with its simple rectangular design of&nbsp;about 4 x&nbsp;2 ½ x 1&nbsp;inches, it was the smallest and lightest AM radio at the time. Sony sold half a million TR-610 sets worldwide between 1958 and 1960. 
The TR-620 was smaller yet. Easily able to fit into a purse or pocket, it appealed to the burgeoning demand for increasingly diminutive and portable personal electronics. It also had a slightly larger station read-out than the TR-610, and the rectangular form was dominated by&nbsp;a gold-toned pierced circular metal speaker with a simple recessed asterisk-like design.&nbsp;The radio&nbsp;was available in several colors, including white, blue, and red, and came with an earphone and black faux leather case&nbsp;as well. The TR-620 was Sony's last transistor radio with&nbsp;a speaker&nbsp;marketed as a shirt-pocket radio.&nbsp; By the mid-1960s, Sony engineers further reduced the radio's size by eliminating the speaker to create an earphone-only radio, which also allowed for cheaper transistors to be used.

tombstone.epitaph: Portable Radio, "Pocketable radio", 1960. Plastic, metal, white metal, cord. Gift of Max Pine. 2012-17-1.
